Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Adaptive Electro-Braille: A New Tactile Sensory Substitution and Assistive Technology for the Blind and Visually Impaired

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Number: 1352006
P.I.: Yantao Shen
Institution: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada-Reno
Title: CAREER: Adaptive Electro-Braille: A New Tactile Sensory Substitution and Assistive Technology for the Blind and Visually Impaired

Broader Significance & Importance:

Advanced assistive technologies are critical to the well-being of the blind and visually impaired (BVI). Touch sensitive displays that can be operated by a variety of users are needed to gain information by the BVI community. Currently technology is not equipped with features that permit the BVI anytime/anywhere access and are not adaptable and convenient for use. This research project will develop tools that are based on electronic scanning technology adapted to a finger-wearable touch device that can be used to scan a variety of objects including Braille text.

Technical Description:

In order to assist the Blind and Visually Impaired (BVI) community to "see", assistive tactile displays that are adaptive, sensorized, individualized, and portable are required. Currently available tactile assistive displays are not equipped with features that permit the BVI to "see" conveniently. This long-term CAREER goal is to facilitate the advances in electrotactile sensing, rendering, and computation into the next generation of smart, individual perception-centered, and portable assistive display to aid the BVI as well to establish a user-friendly and networked infrastructure for enhancing healthcare, learning capabilities and education. In particular, the research objective of this CAREER proposal is to investigate an electrotactile based Braille display technology that is electronic scanning-style, adaptive tactile preference rendering, and finger-wearable. This technology is based on electrical stimulation, and has both online skin bioimpedance sensing and tactile preference rendering functions, called E-Braille. This technology will allow the BVI to conveniently perform important tasks, such as reading, typing in Braille, browsing the Internet, engaging in online conversations, and perceiving graphics. Further, combined with cyber-infrastructure network technology, E-Braille will allow the BVI to conveniently access more documents, books, and libraries, anytime and anywhere. An equally important goal is the recruitment and training of the next generation of engineers who will emerge not only with a solid background in engineering and science disciplines but also have the passion and ability to contribute their expertise in multidisciplinary assistive and rehabilitative engineering areas.
The success of this CAREER project will facilitate research to aid the BVI and will advance our fundamental understanding of electrotactile mechanisms. The major research focus is the development of an adaptive, individual perception-centered, and electrotactile-based Braille display for the BVI, known as E-Braille, which is unique as a fingerwearable electronic device, and will conveniently provide the BVI unlimited access to the information world. The display also will be the first of its kind to include online identification of individual tactile preferences as well as the ability for adaptive tactile preference tuning/rendering for individuals. Currently available Braille displays do not have these features. This CAREER proposal aims to advance the state of the art in portable seeing- assistive devices for the BVI. It will accomplish this goal through the development of EBraille, an affordable and innovative electrical stimulation-based Braille tactile display. This system will offer fast, refreshable information exchange. The proposed adaptive E-Braille will dramatically improve the quality of life of the BVI by allowing them to live more independently and with greater ease. As an integrative part of this project, the PI will develop educational materials inspired by the research results, directed toward students in multidisciplinary engineering program. The research results also will inspire an outreach effort aimed at attracting K-12 students, women, under-represented minorities, and persons with disabilities (e.g., the BVI) to study science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines as well as to participate in this exciting and cutting-edge research project. Finally, both research and educational results will be disseminated by means of presentations at conferences, publications in peer-reviewed journals, web portals, magazines, newspapers, TV and other media, and to the community involved in BVI assistive technology and systems

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aims at discovering advanced assistive technologies and methods that are critical to the wellbeing of the blind and visually impaired (BVI). In particular, the research objective of this project is to investigate an electrotactile-based Braille display technology that is electronic scanning-style, adaptive tactile preference rendering, and finger-wearable. This innovative technology allows programmable electrical stimulation and has both on-line skin bioimpedance sensing and tactile preference rendering functions, called E-Braille. In addition, equally important to the project goal is the recruitment and training of the next-generation of engineers who will emerge not only with a solid background in engineering and science disciplines, but also have the passion and ability to contribute their expertise into multidisciplinary assistive and rehabilitative engineering areas.

The project is successfully completed, and the project outcome and/or findings well address the intellectual merit and broader of impacts of this award. In detail, major outcome/findings in Intellectual Merit are: (1) An adaptive, individual perception-centered, finger-wearable, and refreshable electrotactile-based Braille display for the BVI was successfully developed and prototyped; (2) Its adaptive strategies for on-line bioimpedance sensing of fingertip skin and for rendering tactile preferences were thoroughly investigated and developed; (3) Fingertip skin non-linear properties, perceptual attributes of the electro-tactile stimuli, dynamic spatial mapping and pattern identification, and sub-divisional spatial mapping based on the fingertip bioimpedance feedback were extensively discovered. These findings facilitate the fundamental understanding of the non-linearity properties of fingertip-electrode interface and relevant neuro-electric stimulation mechanisms; (4) A system-level E-Braille-based smart aid for the BVI was validated and a novel opto-neuro-feedback enabled human-in-the-loop control framework for real-time text-line tracking, reading, and Braille translation was established; (5) The investigated E-Braille system and method have been extended to a new surveillance/navigation application for the BVI.

Important outcome/findings about Broader Impacts include: (1) The developed E-Braille is an affordable, innovative, and refreshable electrical stimulation-based Braille tactile display that greatly advances the state of the art in portable "seeing" assistive devices for the BVI; (2) The developed E-Braille allows the BVI to conveniently perform important tasks, such as reading, browsing the Internet, engaging in on-line conversations, and even perceiving graphics. Further, combined with cyber-infrastructure network technology, E-Braille technology enables the BVI to conveniently access more documents, books, and libraries, anytime and anywhere; (3) The project?s findings and results are enriching new educational materials and teaching topics in multidisciplinary biomedical engineering and neurosciences programs; (4) The project resulted in one Ph.D. dissertation, three Master theses; (5) Five female and five male undergraduate students, 2 (one under-represented male and one female) high school students were successively involved in the research work; (6) This project yielded more than 14 publications in peer-reviewed journals and conferences, including one Best Conference Paper award nomination; (7) The project was demonstrated to a number of K-12 outreach programs and public activities/events, including the yearly Engineer?s day, Nevada Bound tours, the Annual Assistive Technology Fairs, Best n Brightest, and yearly senior Capstone Innovation Day; (8) Both research and educational results were disseminated by means of presentations at more than 10 conferences, 16 invited talks/keynote speeches, 7 interviews by medium including KTVN-TV Channel 2, Nevada Today, Reno Gazette-Journal, Accessible Media (AMI, Canada), Kolo 8 (ABC), Communications of the ACM, UNR College of Engineering Magazine.

The outcomes and findings of this research are forming a next-generation novel and adaptive tactile sensory substitution system and infrastructure, which are being made an impact in allowing the blind and visually impaired (BVI) to lead fulfilling and productive lives, and will help the BVI to establish a user-friendly and networked cyber-infrastructure for enhancing their healthcare, learning capabilities and education. The E-Braille system and method will further serve as a scientific means or an effective physical resource for collaborative research in the biomedical and neuroscience fields, involving psychophysicists, neurocytologists, electrochemists, and cognitive scientists. In addition, extended engineering applications and research from the outcomes and findings could include human-robot interaction, robots teleoperation and telepresence, functional neuromuscular stimulation devices that return motor function to the spinal cord injured (SCI), textile e-shopping, bioimpedance based non-invasive blood glucose system and methods, and neuro-feedback computer interfaces.
